title: Man Who Filmed Ahmaud Arbery Shooting Charged With Murder
summary: William Bryan Jr.'s lawyer says he was just a witness. The Georgia Bureau of Investigation arrested the man who filmed the video showing the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery in coastal Glynn County, Ga., and charged him with murder.

title: How to Keep Workers Off the Job
summary: More evidence that the enhanced $600 unemployment benefit will slow the recovery and keep the jobless rate high.. Another 2.4 million Americans filed for jobless benefits last week for a total of 38.6 million in nine weeks. The good news is that as states let businesses reopen, many of these folks should be able to get back to work. But most may have little incentive to, according to a new economic working paper that finds two-thirds are making more unemployed.

title: China Moves on Hong Kong
summary: Beijing plans a new national-security law. Is Taiwan next?. China's forceful takeover of Hong Kong appears to have begun, and threats against Taiwan are rising. That's the message this week as the National People's Congress in Beijing moved to pass an onerous new security law for Hong Kong and the Chinese navy plans to practice an amphibious assault on an island controlled by Taiwan.

title: Susan Rice's Mysterious Email
summary: Team Obama spied on Trump officials and tried to conceal it.. 'I know nothing about this." That's how Susan Rice, President Obama's national security adviser, responded when asked on PBS's NewsHour in March 2017 "whether Trump transition officials, including the President, may have been swept up in surveillance of foreigners at the end of the Obama administration?"

title: A Clear Decision on Open Skies
summary: There's no sense in staying in a treaty that Russia openly violates.. A bright spot in President Trump's foreign policy has been his recognition that treaties are only valuable when every party adheres to them. His decision this week to abandon the 1992 Open Skies accord will cost the U.S. little, but it sends the right message to American adversaries.

title: It's Going to Be a Crazy Summer
summary: Figuring out which recreational facilities are open during the pandemic, and which activities are allowed, will make for some hard decisions. The O'Connors' summer travel plans involve several trips-to the backyard.

title: How to Know Which Risks Are Right for You When Reopening Your Life
summary: A psychologist offers a way to make the tough decisions everybody is facing. As government controls on our behavior diminish, we all have a giant jumble of decisions before us: Should I get my hair cut? Can I hug my mother or best friend? Do I go to a restaurant? Is it time to get on a plane?

title: What It Takes to Become a Contact Tracer on the Trail of the Coronavirus
summary: To safely reopen the economy, the U.S. needs 184,000 contact tracers. Here's who is qualified.. As layoffs continue to mount, one job is in demand in almost all 50 states and urgently requires workers.

title: Four Ways to Make Container Gardening Work for You
summary: Planting flowers in pots is the quickest way to get started in gardening. Here are several strategies to keep container plants thriving.. Planting flowers in containers is the quickest way to get started in gardening. It is much easier than creating a bed in the lawn and requires less maintenance. If you live in an apartment or have a tiny yard, it may be your only option.

title: University of California Will Stop Using SAT, ACT
summary: Admissions tests, allegedly biased against minority students, will be phased out over five years. The University of California board of regents voted Thursday to stop using the SAT and ACT college admissions exams, reshaping college admissions in one of the largest and most prestigious university systems in the country and dealing a significant blow to the multibillion-dollar college admission testing industry.

title: Coronavirus Revives Debate Over Drug Pricing
summary: Lure of profits laid groundwork for some Covid-19 treatments, though may not determine who finds a cure. Not long ago, drug companies had a bull's-eye on their ticker symbols. Sky-high prices for lifesaving drugs and the opioid crisis had made them the country's least-liked industry. Democratic presidential candidates were one-upping each other with promises to rein in prices, while President Trump mulled similar plans.

title: Nvidia Earnings Rise, as Coronavirus Lifts Games and Remote Services
summary: Cloud-computing demand strengthens in pandemic, driving up chip maker's earnings and revenue. Strong growth in computer games and remote computing services, driven by people stuck at home during the coronavirus pandemic, lifted earnings for chip maker Nvidia Corp.

title: For Many, Remote Work Is Becoming Permanent in Wake of Coronavirus
summary: Some companies in Silicon Valley, a business trendsetter, are moving to make remote work the new normal. Companies across the economy are considering a permanent shift to remote work in the aftermath of the coronavirus outbreak, following the lead of tech-sector giants.

title: The Crucial Reopening Question
summary: Organizations need a plan for how to react when a customer or employee tests positive for Covid-19.. If reopening-and staying open-is the goal, the most important question that workplaces, schools, restaurants and retailers should be asking isn't how to maintain social distancing on their premises. Nor is it how to disinfect workspaces or whether to mandate face masks. The most important question is what they will do when an employee, customer, teacher or student tests positive for Covid-19, and what they will do if that person dies.

title: The People's Republic vs. Jimmy Lai
summary: China seeks to imprison a Hong Kong newspaperman and bankrupt his tabloid.. Beijing is moving fast to stifle Hong Kong's democracy movement. It seeks to lock up media tycoon Jimmy Lai and bankrupt his newspaper.

title: A Lost Soul Sought Harbor in the Navy
summary: The future was bleak, the present unbearable. Where could I go?. When Greg Mitrakas said, "Let's join the Navy," it was as if a light suddenly flashed on over my head; as if the sun had burst from a black cloud and illuminated the darkest corners of my dreary world.

title: Islamic Terrorists Win a Convert
summary: An Italian hostage returns home from 18 months in captivity-and sparks a debate.. Rome

title: 'Farnsworth's Classical English Style' Review: The Charm of Novelty
summary: Most books on English style counsel clarity and directness. Fair enough, but what makes clear and direct writing powerful?. Good writing is efficient writing. The ability to say a thing clearly and directly is rather to be chosen than great riches. All the books on English style say so, and they are right. But efficiency, Ward Farnsworth rightly insists, is only the beginning. Although "efficiency is the most important value in most kinds of writing," he writes in "Farnsworth's Classical English Style," "it isn't the only value. Lincoln's writing is clear, but most writing that is clear sounds nothing like Lincoln's and has none of its beauty or strength."

title: Senate Adjourns Without Approving Deal to Extend PPP Spending Window
summary: Senators put off likely passage of revised small-business aid rules to next month. WASHINGTON-The Senate was unable to finalize a deal to extend the amount of time companies have to spend loans obtained through the Paycheck Protection Program, putting off the likely passage of revised small-business aid rules to next month.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended May 16
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Business, Job Market Show Slower Decline
summary: Data show a slower decline in U.S., eurozone and Japan as restrictions begin to ease. U.S. and global business activity and labor markets suffered a little less in May than in prior months, offering signs that damage to the global economy from the coronavirus pandemic is easing but will require an extended time to overcome.

title: Pandemic Poses Most Serious Threat to Fed's Goals 'In Our Lifetimes,' Clarida Says
summary: 'The Covid-19 shock is going to be disinflationary, not inflationary,' says Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida. The coronavirus pandemic poses the most serious threat "in our lifetimes" to the Federal Reserve's goals of maintaining strong employment and stable prices, Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said Thursday.

title: The Healing Power of Proper Breathing
summary: How we inhale and exhale has profound effects on our health-and not just during a crisis like the pandemic. Breathing is not an activity that anyone is feeling confident about right now. We spend our days covering our mouths and noses with masks, struggling to inhale and exhale. We toss and turn at night, worried that we might be feeling a cough coming on or some tightness in our chests. Covid-19 has turned us into a planet of breath-obsessed people.

title: Fall Opening for New York Schools Still Up in Air
summary: Gov. Cuomo waiting until more is known about pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome, a serious condition potentially associated with Covid-19. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said it is too early to tell if New York schools will reopen this fall, as a grim picture emerged of historic job losses in the tri-state area from the region's economic shutdown.

title: Ex-Green Beret, Son Could Face Four Years in Japanese Jail Over Ghosn Escape
summary: Michael L. Taylor and his son Peter M. Taylor were arrested in U.S. at request of Japanese authorities. A former Green Beret and his son face up to four years in a Japanese prison if they are extradited for their suspected role in smuggling Carlos Ghosn out of Japan in a musical equipment box.

title: J.Crew Landlords Pursue Rent From Reopened Stores
summary: Bankrupt retail chain asks judge to let it pause paying rent for all stores until July 6. Dozens of J.Crew Group Inc.'s landlords, including some of the biggest mall owners in the country, are seeking rent payments from the retailer's stores as they reopen, according to court filings.

title: My Boss Wants Me Back at Work. How Do I Keep my Family Safe?
summary: Going back to work isn't a safety concern just for workers. Many fear they'll bring the virus home to vulnerable family members. Here's what to do.. As governors across the country allow more businesses to reopen, employers are calling on workers to return-and prompting a wave of questions from Wall Street Journal readers. One of the most persistent queries: How do I protect vulnerable loved ones and others who share my household?

title: Urban Escapees Provide Some Comfort to Travel Industry
summary: City dwellers may be migrating to home rentals to get out of town this summer amid the coronavirus. Expedia is giving new meaning to the term "cabin fever."

title: 'Grant' Review: The Wisdom and Weaknesses of a Warrior
summary: A History miniseries on Ulysses S. Grant is executed at the highest level.. Ulysses S. Grant was a genius at one thing-waging war. What makes him mythic is the way the fates conspired to snatch him out of obscurity and put him in the precise place and time where his singular gift would change the world. What makes him tragic-and ironic, and maybe even beloved-is the way his temperament, tenacity and undying trust in other humans conspired to lay him low.

title: 'The Trip to Greece' Review: Isles, Miles, Smiles
summary: Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon hit the road again in the last installment of their comedic rambles.. 'The Trip to Greece" gives banter a good name. Also formula, up to a point.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Fear End of the Road
summary: Pro-democracy figures say law would break China's promise to preserve former British colony's way of life. HONG KONG-Beijing's plan to crack down on dissent in Hong Kong with a new security law sent a chill through opposition groups, dealing a blow to a protest movement that nearly a year ago rallied a million people to the streets to halt China's growing influence over the former British colony.

title: 'I Was Lorena Bobbitt' Review: Marking Up History
summary: The woman at the center of the notorious 1990s case offers first-hand info in Lifetime's dramatic account of the story.. Anyone who saw the dynamite documentary "Lorena" on Amazon last year will have a leg up on what's taking place during the breathless opening scene of "I Was Lorena Bobbitt": A distraught woman behind the wheel of a car comes to a screeching halt by an empty lot outside a convenience store, and discovers she has two things in her hands. One is a knife. The other she throws into the night, launching the biggest man(hood)hunt in the history of Manassas, Va. And, of course, one of the bigger media circuses in the last half of the 20th century.

title: Senate Confirms John Ratcliffe as Director of National Intelligence
summary: Vote falls largely along party lines amid disputes over the business of intelligence-gathering. WASHINGTON-A divided Senate confirmed Rep. John Ratcliffe to be President Trump's director of national intelligence, with majority Republicans prevailing over Democrats who said the Texas congressman was too partisan and lacked the qualifications for the job.

title: U.S. Stocks Lose Some Momentum
summary: After big gains earlier in the week, indexes drift lower as 2.4 million Americans filed for unemployment benefits. U.S. stocks slipped Thursday, paring gains from earlier in the week, after data showed another wave of Americans applied for unemployment benefits because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'The Grapes of Wrath' Review: Plain-Spoken and Powerful
summary: A revival of Frank Galati's adaptation of the Steinbeck classic is surprisingly resonant right now..

title: 'The Painter and the Thief' Review: An Engrossing Double Portrait
summary: After two of her paintings are stolen, an artist gets to know one of the perpetrators in Benjamin Ree's documentary.. The best documentary features go beyond the when and how of a given event to plumb the mysteries of what possessed the people involved to do what they did. Benjamin Ree's "The Painter and the Thief" starts with an odd art theft at a gallery in Oslo in 2015-two paintings cut out of their frames and spirited off by a couple of men, one wearing a hoodie and the other a knitted cap, under the gaze of security cameras. The oddity of the crime lay in the value of the art-relatively low, except to the artist, a young Czech woman who was neither famous nor rich. The beauty of the film lies in the bond she forges with one of the thieves after they're found by police and sentenced to 75 days in prison. Questions of identity haunt both the victim and the perp-not their names or addresses, but who they are in the farthest reaches of their psyches, and who they may become.

title: Oil Rally Continues With Supply Cuts Boosting Sentiment
summary: Reduced output, nascent rebound in fuel demand drive down stockpiles in U.S., China. Oil prices climbed Thursday, advancing for the sixth consecutive session with producers curtailing output in response to ultralow crude prices and the coronavirus crisis.

title: Luke's Lobster Navigates Cautious Reopening During the Coronavirus
summary: For restaurants across the country, the summer is a crucial test of survival. Luke's Lobster survived the last recession, opening its first location in New York City's East Village in 2009. Now the seafood chain is up against a bigger challenge: reopening during the middle of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Food 'Souvenirs': Vacations by Proxy
summary: Now's the time to raid the cupboards for those edible souvenirs you brought home from your travels. Running low? We tell you where to buy New Mexican chiles, Port wine from Lisbon and other appetizing items online.. DURING A RECENT purge of the deepest, coldest corners of my freezer, I made a pair of discoveries worthy of Arctic explorer Roald Amundsen. The first: a baggie containing either a Jurassic sausage or a banana escaped from smoothiedom, which I respectfully returned to its frosty home for future generations to ponder.

title: Prices Rise for 20-Year Treasury Bond in Debut
summary: Treasury Department auctioned its first 20-year bonds since 1986 on Wednesday. Prices for the revamped 20-year Treasury bond climbed Thursday in its debut session.

title: Guilt Is Powerful for Those Doing Fine in the Lockdown
summary: People who can work from home feel conflicted about being so fortunate. When people ask how she's doing, Kathren Cavanaugh tries hard not to sound too cheerful.

title: 'Vaccine': Safety From Viruses, Courtesy of the Cows (Maybe)
summary: An 18th-century doctor's success in inoculating against smallpox gets credit for the term, but did his samples come from cows or horses?. After weeks of somber news about the coronavirus pandemic, the appearance of a particular word in headlines was enough to brighten spirits: "vaccine."

title: U.S.-China Trade Deal Is Intact, Kudlow Says
summary: Trump economic adviser also finds Beijing's lack of transparency on coronavirus disappointing. WASHINGTON-White House National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow said Thursday the phase-one trade deal that the U.S. and China negotiated last year was intact and there were no plans to renegotiate.

title: U.S. Moving to Leave 'Open Skies' Treaty Designed to Reduce Conflict With Russia
summary: Accord allows nations to carry out reconnaissance flights over one another's territories to build confidence that an attack isn't being planned. The Trump administration is moving to withdraw from the Open Skies treaty, a nearly three-decade-old accord intended to reduce the risk of war between Russia and the West.

title: Facebook to Shift Permanently Toward More Remote Work After Coronavirus
summary: CEO Mark Zuckerberg sees long-term benefits in working from home, though new tools, techniques to manage policy shift are needed. Mark Zuckerberg is shifting Facebook Inc. toward a substantially remote workforce over the next decade, permanently reconfiguring the tech giant's operations around the dispersed structure that the coronavirus pandemic forced on it.

title: Universities to Their Alumni Networks: Give Our Grads Jobs
summary: With the coronavirus racking the job market, some colleges are working overtime to find paid positions for the class of 2020. Matthew Garza is graduating from Colby College this month. Like many members of the class of 2020, he doesn't have a job lined up. But unlike many of his peers, he isn't too worried.

title: Murray Energy Faces Pivotal Month After Bankruptcy-Loan Default
summary: Loan default could complicate coal producer's negotiations with lenders on potential chapter 11 exit financing. Murray Energy Corp. acknowledged Wednesday that it has defaulted on its $440 million bankruptcy financing package, setting up a pivotal month for the nation's largest private coal producer as it aims to leave chapter 11 amid a market downturn exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Biden Can Get Progressive Vote, but at a Cost
summary: Joe Biden would be well-advised to ignore both Mr. Uygur and Justice Democrats as he fashions his campaign.. Cenk Uygur counsels "How Biden Can Win Over Progressives" (op-ed, May 18). Mr. Uygur self-identifies as a founder of Justice Democrats, a group that "helped elect AOC and the Squad." He says he "can tell you with some authority what progressives think."

title: Once Great UC System's Plan for Mediocrity
summary: It is hard to believe that our best and brightest can think of no better plan to achieve diversity and inclusion than by doing away with measurable academic standards.. Regarding your editorial "California Defines Testing Down" (May 18): University of California President Janet Napolitano's plan to stop using the SAT and ACT in admissions is a natural outgrowth of the University of California's 2015 plan for diversity and faculty development. Faculty were told then to be on the lookout for false claims of color blindness, myths of America's meritocracy, denials of bias, sexist language and pathologizing cultural values. UC's plan to stamp out microaggressions on campus that perpetuate values and styles of dominant white culture was a Band-Aid for a deep wound that predated college and prevented the assemblage of a student-body mosaic perfectly aligned with the overall population mosaic.

title: Premier League Clubs Expect to Pay Rebate on Broadcast Rights
summary: Manchester United became the first to confirm the plan publicly saying it expects to pay £20 million. The 20 clubs of the English Premier League, some of the richest in world soccer, are preparing to refund tens of millions of dollars to broadcasters this year, even if they manage to complete their pandemic-interrupted season.

title: Why Handy Phone Bags Help You WFH Smarter
summary: When the boss calls, there's no 'where's my phone?' panic with these chic pochettes. TINY PHONE TOTES that hang around your neck aren't purse substitutes, but what do you really need to carry in isolation? Whether she's running around the house or the block, Brooklyn publisher Julia Cheiffetz, 41, said her protective pouch grants her a third hand. Plus, it helps cut down on those panicked "where's my phone?" moments.

title: Forecasters Predict Rough Hurricane Season Amid Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: NOAA expects up to 19 named storms overall, including as many as 10 hurricanes. Federal forecasters are predicting an above-average hurricane season amid a pandemic that is forcing emergency managers, aid agencies and utilities to rethink how they mobilize and respond to devastating storms and other disasters.

title: New York City Police Alter Coronavirus Enforcement
summary: Officers to focus on larger crowds in social-distancing efforts. As New York City's outdoor season begins with Memorial Day, police are shifting the focus of their enforcement of social-distancing rules, limiting an emphasis on punitive measures and concentrating on breaking up large groups.

title: U.S. to Invest $1.2 Billion to Secure Potential Coronavirus Vaccine From AstraZeneca, Oxford University
summary: Government to bankroll human trial and ramp-up of manufacturing capacity, hoping to get doses in October. The U.S. government has agreed to hand AstraZeneca PLC up to $1.2 billion to secure the supply of a potential coronavirus vaccine that could be ready as early as October.

title: Minnesota Not Nice
summary: Could a state design a more destructive policy to address coronavirus?. Thank goodness Covid-19 isn't as deadly as many media pundits feared. Given the incomprehensible policy blunders of Minnesota's state government, its health system might have been completely overwhelmed by now.

title: U.N. Worker Dies of Coronavirus in War-Torn Yemen as Cases Surge
summary: Aid agencies warn pandemic could spiral out of control in one of world's most impoverished nations. A United Nations staff member in Yemen died of Covid-19 amid a surge in coronavirus cases, as international agencies warned the pandemic could spiral out of control in one of the world's most impoverished and war-battered nations.

title: Mnuchin: Strong Likelihood We'll Need Another Stimulus Package
summary: Treasury Secretary said there is more than $100 billion left in the federal Paycheck Protection Program; some earn more on unemployment than in jobs. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the U.S. economy "will be great again" in 2021, a day after the Congressional Budget Office forecast that unemployment will remain elevated through the end of next year.

title: Does Bilingualism Make You Smarter?
summary: New research suggests that speaking a second language doesn't affect overall intelligence, upending the conventional wisdom. Perfect fluency in a second language can make someone seem so worldly and intelligent. But does knowing more than one language really make a person smarter?

title: Summer Books 2020: Walking
summary: There's never been a better time to get active and head out on an epic hike-or just a good long walk.. There's a misty-eyed look that comes upon people who have hiked the Appalachian Trail that convinces others there must be something spiritually transcendent about the trek, so I've encountered confusion when I've explained that in my limited experience-I've hiked only a quarter of the AT's 2,200 miles-the reasons the expedition is so memorable are both more modest and more meaningful. The first is about companionship. Forget the myth of the solitary adventurer: The Appalachian Trail is virtually a mosh pit in high season and you leave having forged deep and unforeseen friendships. The second reason has to do with basic physical fitness. Those who can persist beyond the crucible of the first brutal weeks quickly find themselves in better shape than they have been in their entire adult lives.

title: Fed's Williams Optimistic for a Rebound, But Uncertain on Pace
summary: New York Fed leader says central bank has 'unwavering commitment' to limit damage, aid recovery. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said Thursday it is unclear when the U.S. economy will fully recover from the coronavirus pandemic, adding that the central bank will do all it can to help the country navigate the crisis.

title: Kiddie Pools and Other Summer Fun During New York's Lockdown
summary: Bans on swimming at beaches and hoops in parks don't mean there's nothing to do. For New Yorkers, the summer of 2020 has been shaping up as the season of "no." As in no swimming at city beaches or pools. No free Shakespeare in Central Park. No riding the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island.

title: Brace for Another Bad Jobs Report
summary: Job losses appear to be slowing, but the May employment picture still looks horrible. The good news is the job market isn't deteriorating quite as badly in May as it did in April. But actual improvement will have to wait.

title: Nursing Homes Don't Have to Report Pre-May Covid-19 Deaths to U.S. Officials
summary: A May 8 rule requires facilities to submit data on coronavirus cases, but CDC says older information is optional. A recently launched federal effort to collect data on the impact of the coronavirus in nursing homes will leave the full toll unclear, because a new rule doesn't require facilities to report deaths and infections that occurred before early May.

title: Biden Will Answer for FBI Abuse
summary: Barr is right to rule out a criminal probe. Voters will have their say in November.. For millions of Americans frustrated that no Obama-era leaders have been held to account for the Federal Bureau of Investigation's rogue 2016 actions, Attorney General William Barr this week offered an important reminder. Former Vice President Joe Biden, at least, will face judgment in November.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Quorum
summary: The Constitution requires a majority, but under new House rules as few as 20 members could be present.. How can Congress do its work in a time of social distancing? The Senate has remained in session as usual, but the House took steps last week to allow voting by members who aren't in the chamber. Its resolution, passed May 15 without Republican support, is constitutionally faulty and could invalidate every law enacted over the next few months.

title: Family Regroups After Michigan Dam Failure. 'We're Seeing the Worst-Case Scenario.'
summary: Resume Subscription. SANFORD, Mich.-As waters receded here after a massive flood breached two central Michigan dams, Glenn Moots surveyed the damage Wednesday that devastated his home.

title: Workers File 2.4 Million Unemployment Claims
summary: Pace of weekly claims continues to ease from late March peak; self-employed receiving coronavirus-related benefits aren't counted in wave of filings. Workers filed another 2.4 million unemployment claims last week, a slight drop-off in the wave of historically high weekly filings since the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic began.

title: Summer Books 2020: Cycling
summary: A disrupted season of cycling leaves our writer contemplating the sport's past heroes.. As a young boy who dreamed of riding the Tour de France, I devoured any cycling-related book or magazine I could find. That included Peter Nye's detailed yet poetic account of American bicycle racing. First published in 1988, his book helped fuel my ambitions and gave me great insight into the sport's biggest races-how they unfolded, the characters who animated them and the ebb and flow of the sport through periods of change. The second edition of Mr. Nye's book, "Hearts of Lions" (Nebraska, 513 pages, $39.95), has been revised and updated to include the major events of the past 30 years.

title: Summer Books 2020: Nature
summary: Buzzworthy new books on bees, including memoirs from a professional urban beekeeper and an amateur who's just getting started.. When we hear the word "bee" we're likely to imagine the common honey bee or bumblebee. But there are as many as 25,000 recognized bee species in the world-more than birds and mammals combined. Most of these lesser-known bees don't live in hives, many don't sting and relatively few make honey. But since nearly all depend on flowering plants for their food, they have evolved into the most proficient pollinators on the planet.

title: Summer Books 2020: Food
summary: The smell of barbecue may bring Texas to mind, but new books offer a fuller taste of the state.. If, as John Steinbeck wrote, "Texas is a nation in every sense of the word," what better way to understand the state's physical and cultural expanse than through its foodways? A recent handful of cookbooks helps make the case.

title: Summer Books 2020: Summer Reading
summary: Spend quality time with (somebody else's) family and friends.. To describe Emma Straub's novel "All Adults Here" (Riverhead, 356 pages, $27) without using the word "charming" is like trying to describe an accordion without using your hands. But winsome and big-hearted do fine to characterize Ms. Straub's loosely knit, multigenerational fourth novel, which, light tone and light touch notwithstanding, concerns itself with fraught matters: adultery, gender identity and a few instances of sudden death.

title: States Don't Agree on How to Determine When It Is Safe to Reopen
summary: Resume Subscription. After months of lockdowns, all states have now eased restrictions in some capacity, and many are relying on data to tell them when it is safe to move on to the next phase of reopening. But each state has its own idea of what that data should be.

title: Judge Tosses Visium's Lawsuit Against Portfolio Manager's Widow
summary: Jacob Gottlieb's fund had sought more than $100 million. A judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by a hedge fund against the widow of one of the fund's employees.

title: Former Trump Lawyer Cohen Released to Home Confinement
summary: Convicted personal attorney will serve sentence at home because of coronavirus concerns. President Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen was released from a federal prison Thursday due to coronavirus concerns and is expected to serve the rest of his three-year sentence at home, his lawyer said.

title: Covid-19 Deaths Likely Missed in Michigan, Data Suggest
summary: Analysis in the hard-hit state underscores broader challenges of assessing virus's toll. Fresh data from Michigan, one of the states hardest hit by the new coronavirus, show that a testing shortfall there is likely fueling a substantial undercount of deaths attributed to Covid-19 and points to the broader challenge of tracking deaths from the disease nationwide.

title: Live Theater in Your Living Room?
summary: New York City's Public Theater and other playhouses are migrating online-via Zoom and Facebook Live performances-and everyone gets a front row seat. THOSE MISSING the thrill of live theater can tap into it virtually (and gratis), bellowing 'bravo' from the couch, thanks to Broadway's new Zoom experiments. "What makes theater powerful is it's happening in real time, with real actors, and nobody can totally control it," said Oskar Eustis, the artistic director for New York City's Public Theater, who fast-tracked a virtual iteration of new Richard Nelson play "What Do We Need to Talk About." The result? "There is an intimacy [online] that's not a substitute for a live presence, but the level of detail you see in the actors' reactions is beautiful," he said. The play, live-streaming until June 28 on publictheater.org, garnered 47,000 views in 30 countries in its first four days.

title: Best Buy Could Have Been Much Worse
summary: Best Buy's ability to retain sales after closing down all of its U.S. stores speaks to its hold on the electronics and appliances market. Best Buy is a survivor, and last quarter's results show it.

title: Harold Hamm, Fracking Pioneer, Faces a Career Reckoning
summary: Resume Subscription. Harold Hamm, the wildcatter who helped usher in the American fracking boom, has weathered his share of oil busts. None of them matched this one.

title: Behind Trump's Removal of Inspectors General: Support for His Agenda
summary: He views himself 'a victim of overly aggressive actions,' according to one senior administration official. WASHINGTON-President Trump's firing of the State Department inspector general is the latest move in his effort to restock the federal government with officials he sees as supportive of his agenda, according to advisers, after what he sees as a series of politically motivated investigations into him and his top allies.

title: Converse CEO John O'Neil Kept All Star Shoes in Game
summary: As Nike grabbed the running market, canvas sneakers became a fashion statement.

title: Starbucks Pushes To-Go Sales as Dine-In Operations Remain Closed
summary: Coffee chain plans more drive-through locations, mall closures. Starbucks Corp. said it is speeding up plans to build stores with drive-throughs and will close locations in unpopulated malls as its dine-in service remains suspended due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A Natural Gas Exec Turned His Colorado Ranch Into a 'Mini Country Club.' Now He's Selling It for $220 Million.
summary: Resume Subscription. Over the past seven years, Egypt-born entrepreneur Charif Souki has poured many millions of dollars into his 813-acre Colorado ranch, he said, turning it into something akin to a "mini-country club" for his family.

title: A Colorado Ranch Asks $220 Million
summary: An entrepreneur built a "mini-country club" for his family with plenty of amenities.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Macy's Names Interim CFO as Retailer Navigates Coronavirus Pandemic
summary: Felicia Williams is set to replace outgoing finance chief Paula Price on an interim basis. Macy's Inc. promoted an internal candidate to replace outgoing finance chief Paula Price on an interim basis, a move that comes as the storied retailer is battling the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on its business.

title: S&P Fired Employee Who Discussed Ratings With Senate Staff
summary: Wrongful-termination complaint claims retaliation for discussing a taboo topic; firm says employee violated policy. In November, an S&P Global Inc. employee briefed Senate Banking Committee staff members on the growing risks in the $1.2 trillion market for loans that finance private-equity buyouts.

title: Sleuthing Through the Ages
summary: From Oedipus to Sherlock Holmes, readers have flocked to stories about determined detectives.. I have to confess that I've spent the lockdown reading thrillers and whodunits. But judging by the domination of mystery titles on the bestseller lists, so has nearly everyone else. In uncertain times, crime fiction offers certainty, resolution and comfort.

title: U.S. Existing-Home Sales Dropped 17.8% in April
summary: Sales post biggest monthly decline since July 2010, as coronavirus shut down much of country's economic activity. Sales of previously owned homes plunged in April, as the coronavirus pandemic shut down much of the country's economic activity and sellers and buyers stayed on the sidelines.

title: Next in Videoconferencing-Hiding Your On-Screen Double Chin
summary: Lockdown computer conversations reveal that webcams add about 10 pounds under the jawline; 'I didn't realize I was this vain'. Liza Lane was about to begin a videoconference lecture to her University of Houston students recently when she noticed something horrible on the screen: the dreaded double chin.

title: A New 40% Rule for Grimmer Times
summary: Economists move in herds, even as the economy collapses. The 40% rule is a time-tried tactic employed by pundits making forecasts. If you say there is a 40% chance of something improbable happening and it does, you look great. And if it doesn't, you never said the odds favored it. But in the Covid-19 era, the 40% number economists are now citing is how much they expect gross domestic product to contract, at an annual rate, in the second quarter.

title: Amazon Targets Fall for Prime Day as it Tries to Return to Pre-Pandemic Operations
summary: E-commerce giant also allows nonessential goods shipments, indication of wider variety of products. Amazon.com Inc. is taking a number of steps to return to pre-pandemic business operations, including scheduling its annual Prime Day shopping promotion for the fall and allowing unlimited shipments of nonessential goods to warehouses, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Doctors on the Theodore Roosevelt Feared Dozens Would Die in Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: 'Get everyone off the ship,' aircraft carrier's medical team implored, as Capt. Brett Crozier called for rapid action.

title: Loughlin to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
summary: Plea agreements for the actress and her husband, designer Mossimo Giannulli, include prison time. Actress Lori Loughlin and her husband, fashion designer Mossimo Giannulli, have agreed to plead guilty to fraud conspiracy charges in connection with their involvement in the nationwide college admissions cheating scandal.

title: Coronavirus Costs Raise Questions for Next Defense Authorization Bill
summary: Some liberals float cuts to Pentagon to support higher public-health spending after emergency period ends. WASHINGTON-The coronavirus pandemic is fueling new debates about government funding, including for the Pentagon, as lawmakers grapple with where to find extra money to fight the disease once the immediate emergency has passed.

title: How Lady Gaga Pivoted Her Major Album Release
summary: No stadium tours, no festivals-no problem? Pop superstar Lady Gaga's longtime manager Bobby Campbell on tactically changing the release of her much-hyped Chromatica. Although it seems unfathomable now, Lady Gaga announced a six-city stadium tour across North America and Europe on March 5. About three weeks later, all her tour dates were on hold. Elaborate release plans for her sixth studio album, Chromatica, were completely scrapped.

title: Why the World's Most Debt-Squeezed Company Is Buying Back Shares
summary: However shaky it looks, betting against China's biggest property developer is extremely risky. It's been a bad year for buybacks. Except, that is, for the company with the largest debt interest bill of any nonfinancial-listed stock on the planet, according to Capital IQ.

title: These High-End Home Offices Mean Business
summary: With telecommuting on the rise, homeowners are carving out luxurious work-from-home spaces. When Nilesh Dayal and his wife, Kristal Jackson Dayal, built their 9,400-square-foot Mediterranean-style house in Houston in 2016, they created a stately home office they expected to use for after-dinner work, nighttime calls to foreign time zones and occasional client meetings.

title: Top Mental-Health Official Warns Against a Second Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: Comments highlight growing concern over the toll the shutdown is taking on mental health. A second coronavirus lockdown could pose grave risks to the nation's mental health, the country's leading mental-health official said.

title: Coronavirus Raises Demand for Skin-Temperature Scanners
summary: Surging interest for infrared devices, which can flag higher skin temperatures without close contact, has imaging firms rushing to refocus their businesses. A coronavirus-triggered rush for infrared cameras that identify people with elevated skin temperature is causing makers of the devices to beef up supply chains and re-examine their product lineups to meet the increasing requests coming from different businesses.

title: More Fridges, More Food: Our Homes Are Making Us Fat
summary: Americans are packing on the pounds thanks to home automation, extra refrigeration and excessive screen time. It isn't bad enough that we're mostly stuck at home where the fridge is so close, and that we're stress eating while trying to do our jobs on a card table in the bedroom. We're also fighting an unexpected enemy in our quest to not become Jabba the Hutt.

title: Europe's Recovery Imperiled by Banks Too Scared to Lend
summary: Bank loans were expected to quickly reach those in need under government-guarantee plans. So far, progress is slow.. In late March, Angelica Donati, an Italian infrastructure and real-estate entrepreneur, started calling local banks seeking a loan to shore up her business after it was shut during Rome's battle to contain the coronavirus.

title: Americans Are Cooking More Seafood, but Fishermen Are Struggling
summary: Without restaurant orders keeping them afloat, seafood companies are trying new lures to get fish on people's plates. The coronavirus crisis is hitting seafood businesses even harder than the meat industry, prompting fishermen and processors to overhaul their operations and look for new customers.

title: Actually, There Will Be Spitting in Baseball-When Players Are Tested
summary: MLB's plan for playing through coronavirus involves what may be the most high-profile use of saliva tests, rather than swabs, to screen for infection. In the bizarro season Major League Baseball hopes to have this summer, players will be forced to do the unthinkable in order to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus: refrain from spitting, a tradition as much a part of the game as the ceremonial first pitch and seventh-inning stretch.

title: Hospitals Brace for Mental-Health Crisis Among Doctors and Nurses
summary: In areas where the coronavirus has rampaged, medical staff has been worn thin; 'like a movie, but a horror film'. Even as they battle a virus that has claimed more than 90,000 lives in the U.S., hospitals are scrambling to address another onslaught: a mental-health crisis in their ranks.

title: As Lockdown Eases, Italy Confronts an Epidemic of Poverty
summary: Resume Subscription. NAPLES, Italy-Giovanni Bruno first realized Italy was dealing with an unprecedented crisis when the food bank he runs started getting calls for help from middle-class Italians.

title: Beware Buyer's Remorse as Biotech Firms Rush to Sell Shares
summary: Coronavirus pandemic has fired up interest in sector as investors eye vaccine developers. Investor enthusiasm for biotechnology stocks is running hot. That could be a sign that the sector's spring rally will soon wind down.

title: Japan Further Lifts Coronavirus State of Emergency
summary: Order is eased around Osaka but remains in place in Tokyo. TOKYO-Japan lifted a state of emergency from its second-largest urban region, around Osaka, but kept the restriction in force for the Tokyo area, where new coronavirus infections have been slightly higher but are trending down.

title: Wishful Thinking Makes This a Tough Market to Beat
summary: This week's wild stock swings can in part be explained by investors betting on what they want to happen. Investors are just as prone to wishful thinking as anyone else, but this week's wild stock swings showed that even unwarranted hope can be applied entirely rationally.

title: Australia Is Getting Dragged Into the Trump-Xi Trade War
summary: Playing U.S. and Australian farmers off each other probably looks like a win-win in Beijing. Love triangles have long been staple fare for soap operas and Hollywood dramas. Now they are becoming a recurring feature of global agricultural trade as well.

title: Britain's Big Dividend Reset
summary: Cash returns once seen as sacrosanct have been cut during this crisis and seem unlikely to rebound soon. It has been a rough year for dividends so far and is likely to get worse. Investors reliant on big British payers have particular reason to worry.

title: Media Company Whistle Buys Marketing Firm to Capture Ad Spending by Streaming Services
summary: Marketing firm Tiny Horse works for streamers including Netflix and Amazon. Team Whistle, a digital media company known for its sports and entertainment programming on social platforms, has acquired the marketing firm Tiny Horse LLC, partly to capture more business from intensely competitive video streaming services.

title: Trump, Biden Campaign Spending Plunged in April
summary: Neither candidate held an in-person campaign event last month, when stay-at-home orders were in place in many states. The top presidential candidates' campaign spending plummeted last month as the coronavirus pandemic kept President Trump and presumptive Democratic nominee Joe Biden close to home, newly filed Federal Election Commission reports show.

title: The Best Clippers for Quarantine Haircuts? We Asked Barbers
summary: With these barber-tested tools, that overdue DIY trim needn't be traumatic. UNTIL THEIR STRIPED poles revolve again, the quarantined barbers we spoke to have faith that America's men can keep themselves looking respectable. To justify their optimism, you'll need a good set of clippers, a set of guards to achieve the right hair length and maybe a patient YouTube video explanation or two.

title: China Cuts Mingling, Adds Live Streams to Keep Legislative Sessions Coronavirus-Free
summary: Beijing is staging its most important political meeting of the year amid fears of a second wave of infections. After months of struggle, China has gotten most of its economy back on track. Now, it is having to get creative as it stages its most important political meeting of the year-a gathering of thousands of delegates-amid fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections.

title: Coronavirus Lockdowns Spark Boom in Online Learning for Adults, Too
summary: The online business of teaching skills like writing, calligraphy or languages thrives; 'we're all seeing the minutes skyrocket'. From her home in Portland, Ore., Peggy Dean perches her iPhone on a tripod and records five-minute lessons on subjects ranging from modern calligraphy to watercolor. Since the coronavirus struck, demand for her videos has soared, with viewing figures doubling from a year ago.

title: She Has Argued 40 Cases in Front of the Supreme Court. The Latest Was From Her Dining Room.
summary: Attorney Lisa Blatt's prep for telephonic arguments included broken lectern and virtual practice sessions. The U.S. Supreme Court this month heard telephonic arguments as the coronavirus pandemic prevented in-person sessions. It represented a historic chapter for the court and a potential template for attorneys who might need to master remote sessions if courtrooms remain virtual.

title: SBA Under Spotlight as Frustrations With Small-Business Aid Program Grow
summary: Bipartisan lawmakers push agency for more transparency about its response to small businesses hit by coronavirus closures. WASHINGTON-Since its launch nearly two months ago, the government's rescue effort for small businesses has been peppered with complaints over terms of the loan programs and the piecemeal way the programs have been implemented.

title: Coronavirus Shutdown Casts Doubt on Value of Exchange Trading Floors
summary: NYSE's 4 p.m. auctions run more smoothly, study finds; investors get better prices for S&P 500 options. Investors won't necessarily benefit when the New York Stock Exchange and other market operators welcome traders back to their closed floors, new research suggests.

title: Large Tech Companies Prepare for Acquisition Spree
summary: Tighter market for tech tools could leave fewer options for cash-strapped CIOs, industry analysts say. After pushing the pause button during the coronavirus pandemic, big enterprise-technology companies later this year are expected to go on a shopping spree for smaller tech firms, industry analysts say.

title: As U.S. Pressures Huawei, Chinese Chip Stocks Soar
summary: The Chinese government is eager to become self-sufficient in key technologies. Chinese semiconductor stocks have soared recently, as investors bet these companies will benefit from Beijing's quest for high-tech self-reliance.

title: At Least Three People Shot at Arizona Shopping Center
summary: Suspected gunman taken into custody after shooting at shopping center in suburban Phoenix; police are looking into a video posted on Snapchat. At least three people were shot at a shopping center in suburban Phoenix on Wednesday evening, police said, in one of the first shootings at a public space in the U.S. since the coronavirus pandemic began.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Coronavirus Widens the Retail Divide: Macy's Sales Fall 45%, Best Buy Slips 6%
summary: Macy's expects $1 billion quarterly loss; Victoria's Secret to close 250 North American stores; Best Buy benefits from curbside pickups. The coronavirus pandemic is widening the divide between retailers that are drawing shoppers and those that are losing business, accelerating a split that had been playing out before the health crisis forced some chains to temporarily close stores.

title: Trump Upbraids Michigan, Nevada for Easing Vote-by-Mail
summary: President threatens to withhold funding from the states for plans to mail out absentee-ballot applications. President Trump stepped up his criticism of voting by mail, threatening to withhold federal funds from Michigan and Nevada for their efforts to expand mail-in voting to address health concerns over the coronavirus pandemic.

title: China's Xi Seeks to Portray Unity and Pivot to Economy Under Coronavirus Shadow
summary: Lawmakers to join Chinese leader in Beijing for the first major political gathering since the pandemic. HONG KONG-Chinese leader Xi Jinping is racing to revive a battered economy as he tries to project a united Communist Party and quash dissent against his authority.

title: Canada Goose Cutting About 125 Jobs
summary: Maker of luxury jackets cites impact of Covid-19 for restructuring. Canada Goose Holdings Inc. has laid off about 125 workers, as the coronavirus pandemic saps demand for the company's luxury fur-trimmed jackets.

title: Some Senate Republicans Urge Quicker Action on Coronavirus Aid
summary: Colorado's Cory Gardner seeks more state aid, changes to small-business loan rules before any recess. WASHINGTON-Some vulnerable Senate Republicans expressed frustration over the party's go-slow approach on the next round of coronavirus relief, urging quicker action to counter the pandemic as re-election concerns start to play a more prominent role on Capitol Hill.

title: Supreme Court Blocks Disclosure of Mueller Materials
summary: Ruling shields grand-jury materials while administration argues they should remain secret. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court blocked Congress from receiving grand-jury materials from Robert Mueller's investigation of Russia's interference in the 2016 election, likely extending the issue past November's election.

title: Failed Michigan Dam Lost License in 2018
summary: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission cited operator Boyce Hydro Power for safety concerns. MIDLAND, Mich.-A central Michigan dam failure Tuesday requiring mass evacuations left the state and residents struggling to juggle a natural disaster amid a global pandemic.

title: All 50 States Have Now Taken Steps to Reopen
summary: Slight declines in new cases prompt governors to ease restrictions, hoping to revive economies. The U.S. hit a milestone in the coronavirus pandemic as all 50 states have now begun reopening, working to revive their economies after months of shutdowns designed to curb the contagion.

title: Intelligence Chief Is Asked to Declassify Flynn Conversations
summary: Sen. Mark Warner also requests intelligence reports compiled during Trump's presidential transition. WASHINGTON-President Trump's acting intelligence chief was asked Wednesday by a leading Senate Democrat to declassify all intelligence reports of conversations between Michael Flynn and Russia's former ambassador, which led to his prosecution on charges of lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as part of the investigation by former special counsel Robert Mueller.

title: U.S. Orders Breakup of Exoskeleton Firm's Venture With Chinese Investors
summary: Scrutiny has increased since Congress cracked down in 2018 on businesses' growing reliance on foreign money. WASHINGTON-A U.S. national security panel has ordered the breakup of a joint venture formed between Chinese investors and a California firm that makes exoskeletons, robotic devices that can help disabled people walk but can also help soldiers carry heavy loads.
